messages.message: Hey turkey. I’m just saying hi and wondering what your thoughts are on Rum and Gre? Serb is traditionally Austrian territory and Bul goes to Turkey. I’m just wondering how the Russian situation is going to shake out. Also, would you be open to sharing information you hear about me with me in exchange for Russian intel?
messages.input: Message from AUSTRIA:'Hey turkey. I’m just saying hi and wondering what your thoughts are on Rum and Gre? Serb is traditionally Austrian territory and Bul goes to Turkey. I’m just wondering how the Russian situation is going to shake out. Also, would you be open to sharing information you hear about me with me in exchange for Russian intel?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. AUSTRIA's friendly opening and proposal to share information in exchange for Russian intel indicate a cooperative attitude and a potential for collaboration, making it a promising start to building trust and alliances in the game.

messages.message: Hi, I am willing to work with you, at least in the intel sharing part. I would be happy if we split Rum and Gre in a way that steers us away from each other.
messages.input: My response to AUSTRIA:'Hi, I am willing to work with you, at least in the intel sharing part. I would be happy if we split Rum and Gre in a way that steers us away from each other.'.

messages.message: I can’t speak to the split now, but if we do split it me Gre you Rum, I propose that you only put Fleets in Rum and I only put armies in Greece. If you’d rather I put a fleet in that’s OK too
messages.input: Message from AUSTRIA:'I can’t speak to the split now, but if we do split it me Gre you Rum, I propose that you only put Fleets in Rum and I only put armies in Greece. If you’d rather I put a fleet in that’s OK too'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. AUSTRIA's proposal for splitting Rum and Gre with coordinated unit types shows a willingness to negotiate and coordinate effectively, indicating a genuine effort to establish a mutually beneficial arrangement for both parties.

messages.message: That is reasonable but then that would mean you and Italy fight while it is me against Russia. What about a reverse? I get Gre? Would that work for you at all?
messages.input: My response to AUSTRIA:'That is reasonable but then that would mean you and Italy fight while it is me against Russia. What about a reverse? I get Gre? Would that work for you at all?'.

messages.message: Why does being in Greece commit me to the Italian front? Galicia is crucial to taking Russia.
messages.input: Message from AUSTRIA:'Why does being in Greece commit me to the Italian front? Galicia is crucial to taking Russia.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. AUSTRIA's logical argument about the importance of Galicia for pressuring Russia and questioning the assumption that controlling Greece automatically leads to conflict with Italy indicates a thoughtful approach to strategic decision-making and a rational analysis of the game dynamics.

messages.message: Because what will italy do in that case? He is the eastern power and he will definitely be looking for greece for himself. Also if you take greece and then commit to fight russia, ehat do i get from that? You got easy greece for you while I have to fight for everything. Hopefully you understand my point here.
messages.input: My response to AUSTRIA:'Because what will italy do in that case? He is the eastern power and he will definitely be looking for greece for himself. Also if you take greece and then commit to fight russia, ehat do i get from that? You got easy greece for you while I have to fight for everything. Hopefully you understand my point here.'.

messages.message: That’s fair. It’ll also make more sense for me to not mess around in Greece and build an army while you focus navy. If we structure our build types well, we can keep the relationship fairly balanced. I think I might be able to sneak some Italian gains early on and am considering moving that direction if Russia stays out of Gal in 1901. If it works, you won’t have to worry about a Lepanto.
messages.input: Message from AUSTRIA:'That’s fair. It’ll also make more sense for me to not mess around in Greece and build an army while you focus navy. If we structure our build types well, we can keep the relationship fairly balanced. I think I might be able to sneak some Italian gains early on and am considering moving that direction if Russia stays out of Gal in 1901. If it works, you won’t have to worry about a Lepanto.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. AUSTRIA's strategic reasoning and proposal to maintain balanced unit builds while considering potential gains against Italy demonstrate a cooperative mindset and a commitment to thoughtful planning, suggesting a genuine interest in working together effectively in the game.

messages.message: Okay, how this might go then if Russia enters Galicia? That could be a trouble for you and trouble for me
messages.input: My response to AUSTRIA:'Okay, how this might go then if Russia enters Galicia? That could be a trouble for you and trouble for me'.

messages.message: I don’t think that’s going to happen. If it does, I’ll be able to survive long enough for England, you, or Germany to distract him. You could always open to Armenia?
messages.input: Message from AUSTRIA:'I don’t think that’s going to happen. If it does, I’ll be able to survive long enough for England, you, or Germany to distract him. You could always open to Armenia?'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. AUSTRIA's confident response and strategic foresight regarding the potential situation in Galicia show a clear understanding of the dynamics and a willingness to adapt and strategize accordingly with a contingency plan in place, indicating a trustworthy and engaged approach to the game.

messages.message: I’m moving my fleet to Alb not for Greece but for Italy. Just a heads up
messages.input: Message from AUSTRIA:'I’m moving my fleet to Alb not for Greece but for Italy. Just a heads up'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. AUSTRIA's transparent communication about their fleet movement to Albania, clarifying the target as Italy rather than Greece, demonstrates honesty and strategic openness, indicating a reliable and direct approach to sharing intentions in the game.

messages.message: Russia has indicated that he is not going to move F Sev - Rum. Just letting a friend know so that you can bounce him.
messages.input: Message from AUSTRIA:'Russia has indicated that he is not going to move F Sev - Rum. Just letting a friend know so that you can bounce him.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. AUSTRIA's sharing of information about Russia's indicated move from Sevastopol to Romania, allowing you to anticipate and counteract it, displays a cooperative and supportive attitude, indicating reliability and a willingness to collaborate effectively in the game.

messages.message: Okay I will go for Rum, but he is probably going to support himself there, so I reckon Galicia is safe.
messages.input: My response to AUSTRIA:'Okay I will go for Rum, but he is probably going to support himself there, so I reckon Galicia is safe.'.

messages.message: Wow, you really think I would fall for that?
